data.title: FRANCE: FRENCH PRIME MINISTER AND PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE EDOUARD BALLARDUR APPEARS IN PUBLIC AFTER 2 OPINION POLLS INDICATE PARIS MAYOR JACQUES CHIRAC CLEAR FAVOURITE TO WIN ELECTION.
data.meta_description: Search and license clips from Reuters vast archive of news video footage, dating back to 1896
data.text:
Title: FRANCE: FRENCH PRIME MINISTER AND PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE EDOUARD BALLARDUR APPEARS IN PUBLIC AFTER 2 OPINION POLLS INDICATE PARIS MAYOR JACQUES CHIRAC CLEAR FAVOURITE TO WIN ELECTION.

Summary: PARIS, FRANCE (MARCH 2 AND 3, 1995) (RTV - ACCESS ALL) (MARCH 2) 1. GV FRENCH PRIME MINISTER EDOUARD BALLADUR ARRIVING AT HEADQUARTERS FOR HIS PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN 0.16 2. SLV INT. BALLADUR SURROUNDED BY CHANTING SUPPORTERS 0.24 3. MCU/SV AUDIENCE/BALLADUR SPEAKING TO SUPPORTERS (FRENCH) (7 SHOTS) 1.25 (MARCH 3) 4. SLV/CRANE DOWN/SV EXTERIOR OF PARIS TOWN HALL(3 SHOTS) 1.33 5. SLV/SV PARIS MAYOR JACQUES CHIRAC LEAVING TOWN HALL WITH SOUTH KOREAN PRESIDENT KIM YOUNG-SAM (2 SHOTS) 1.57 6. SV TWO MEN TALKING 2.04 7. SV CHIRAC AND WIFE, CLAUDE, SAYING GOODBYE/ ZOOM-OUT (2 SHOTS) 2.08 Initials Script is copyright Reuters Limited. All rights reserved.

Embargoed: 17th March 1995 12:00

Keywords:

Location: PARIS, FRANCE

City:

Country: France

Reuters ID: LVABBW3JO41SD56Q0TM2E60QXAIW

Story Text: French Prime Minister and presidential candidate Edouard Balladur put on a brave face on Friday (March 3) after two opinion polls indicated Paris Mayor Jacques Chirac was clear favourite to win the election.

The surveys provided the worst showing so far for Balladur, who has long been the favourite to win the two-stage election starting on April 23.

Balladur, Interior Minister Charles Pasqua and Budget Minister Nicolas Sarkozy attended the inauguration of the Parisian supporters committee on Thursday.

Balladur was greeted by supporters shouting "Balladur President".

A key Balladur supporter, Pasqua dismissed the polls saying the polls would rise and fall again before the vote.

Asked about the opinion polls, Balladur said: "I am confident in the outcome of the presidential election." "I remember that for a period of two years, when the opinion polls were extremely favourable, people criticized what they called the polls-mania and the manipulation of public opinion," he said.
